query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 Ma poi che l’altre vergini dier loco 8 a lei di dir, levata dritta in pè, 9 rispuose, colorata come foco:
10 ‘Modicum, et non videbitis me; 11 et iterum, sorelle mie dilette, 12 modicum, et vos videbitis me’.
query.result:
**English:**
7 But after the other virgins gave place 8 to her to speak, standing upright on her feet, 9 she replied, flushed as fire:
10 ‘A little while, and you will not see me; 11 and again, my dear sisters, 12 a little while, and you will see me’.
**Old English:**
7 Ac ða ða ða oðre fæmnan geafon rum 8 hyre to sprecanne, arisan uprihte, 9 andswarode ða, bleoh bigleowed:
10 ‘Modicum, and ge me ne geseoð; 11 and eft, mine leofan sweostor, 12 modicum, and ge me geseoð’.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 Poi le si mise innanzi tutte e sette, 14 e dopo sé, solo accennando, mosse 15 me e la donna e ’l savio che ristette.
query.result:
**English:**
13 Then all seven of them placed themselves in front of her, 14 and behind her, with just a gesture, she moved 15 me and the lady and the wise man who stayed behind.
**Old English:**
13 Þa hire foran ealle seofon 14 and hire æfter, beornas geapnede, 15 mec and ða meowlan and ðone mæran þegn.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 Sì com’ io fui, com’ io dovëa, seco, 23 dissemi: «Frate, perché non t’attenti 24 a domandarmi omai venendo meco?».
query.result:
**English:**
22 Just as I was, as I had to be, with him, 23 he said to me: "Brother, why do you not dare 24 to ask me anything now that you are coming with me?".
**Old English:**
22 Swa swa ic wæs, swa ic sceolde beon, mid him, 23 cwæð to me: "Broðor, hwi ne dearst ðu 24 me ahsian nu ða ðu eart cumen mid me?".

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Come a color che troppo reverenti 26 dinanzi a suo maggior parlando sono, 27 che non traggon la voce viva ai denti,
28 avvenne a me, che sanza intero suono 29 incominciai: «Madonna, mia bisogna 30 voi conoscete, e ciò ch’ad essa è buono».
query.result:
**English:**
25 Like one who is too reverent 26 in speaking before his superior, 27 so that he does not form the words clearly,
28 it happened to me that, without a full voice, 29 I began: "My lady, you know my need 30 and what is good for it."
**Old English:**
25 Swa swa ðone ðe bið to ðearle eaðmod 26 ðonne he ðone selestan secgan wile, 27 ðæt he ða word ne mæg wyrpan of ðam muðe,
28 swa wæs me ða ða ic ða spræce ongann 29 ðurh ða micclan ege ðe me on innan wæs: 30 "Hlæfdige, ðu wast ða neode mine 31 and ðæt ðe ðearf is selast."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
31 Ed ella a me: «Da tema e da vergogna 32 voglio che tu omai ti disviluppe, 33 sì che non parli più com’ om che sogna.
query.result:
**English:**
31 And she to me: "From fear and from shame 32 I want you now to free yourself, 33 so that you no longer speak like one who dreams.
**Old English:**
31 And heo to me: "Of ðære fyrhte and of ðære scame 32 ic wille ðæt ðu ðe nu genimete, 33 swa ðæt ðu ne sprece na mare swa swa mon ðe slæpeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 Sappi che ’l vaso che ’l serpente ruppe, 35 fu e non è; ma chi n’ha colpa, creda 36 che vendetta di Dio non teme suppe.
query.result:
**English:**
34 Know that the vessel that the serpent broke, 35 was and is not; but let him who is guilty believe 36 that God's vengeance does not fear bribes.
**Old English:**
34 Wite ðu ðæt ðæt fæt ðæt ðe nædre tobærst, 35 wæs and nis; ac se ðe ðæs gylt hæfð, gelyfe 36 ðæt Godes wracu ne ondræt nænne gafol.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
37 Non sarà tutto tempo sanza reda 38 l’aguglia che lasciò le penne al carro, 39 per che divenne mostro e poscia preda;
40 ch’io veggio certamente, e però il narro, 41 a darne tempo già stelle propinque, 42 secure d’ogn’ intoppo e d’ogne sbarro,
43 nel quale un cinquecento diece e cinque, 44 messo di Dio, anciderà la fuia 45 con quel gigante che con lei delinque.
query.result:
**English:**
37 It will not be always without an heir 38 the eagle who left its feathers to the chariot, 39 because of which it became a monster and then prey;
40 for I see certainly, and therefore I tell it, 41 that stars already close at hand will give us the time, 42 free from every obstacle and every hindrance,
43 in which a five hundred, ten and five, 44 sent by God, will kill the she-wolf 45 with that giant who sins with her.
**Old English:**
37 Ne bið ðæt ealles unawended 38 se earn ðe ða fjeðre let ðam cræte, 39 ðurh ðæt he wearð to wyrme and ða to wulfe;
40 ðæt ic gesyhð gewislice, and ðæs ic secgan dear, 41 ðæt us sceal ðurh steorran sum, ðe us nu steoreð, 42 æfter wundrum miclum weorðan gecyðed,
43 on ðam feorðan geare and ðam fif and hundteontigðan, 44 ðæt se halga God of heofonum sendeð 45 sumne mannan to ðisse moldan, ðe ða mænige sceal,

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
52 Tu nota; e sì come da me son porte, 53 così queste parole segna a’ vivi 54 del viver ch’è un correre a la morte.
query.result:
**English:**
52 You take note; and just as they are carried by me, 53 so mark these words to the living 54 of the life that is a running to death.
**Old English:**
52 Þu gehyr nu; and swa swa hi fram me synd geferode, 53 swa þas word gecyð þam lybbendum 54 be þam life þe is an yrnende to ðam deade.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 E aggi a mente, quando tu le scrivi, 56 di non celar qual hai vista la pianta 57 ch’è or due volte dirubata quivi.
query.result:
**English:**
55 And keep in mind, when you write to her, 56 not to conceal what you have seen of the plant 57 that has now been cut down here twice.
**Old English:**
55 And gemyne ðu ðonne ðu ðis gewritu, 56 ðæt ðu ne læte ðæt ðu ða wyrte forhele, 57 ðe ðær nu ðis oðre siðe bið forcorfen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 Qualunque ruba quella o quella schianta, 59 con bestemmia di fatto offende a Dio, 60 che solo a l’uso suo la creò santa.
query.result:
**English:**
58 Whoever fells this tree or that, 59 with the act of destruction offends God, 60 who created it holy for his use alone.
**Old English:**
58 Swa hwylc swa ðæt treow ðær oððe ðær afylð, 59 mid dy geleaffullican dædum Gode he onscunað, 60 se ðe hit ana to his agenre note halig gesceop.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Per morder quella, in pena e in disio 62 cinquemilia anni e più l’anima prima 63 bramò colui che ’l morso in sé punio.
query.result:
**English:**
61 To bite into that fruit, in pain and desire 62 for five thousand years and more the first soul 63 yearned, he who punished the bite on himself.
**Old English:**
61 Þæt heo ðæt bite, on pîne and on geornfulnesse, 62 fif þusend wintra and ma leng 63 wilnode se ðe ðone wæstm on him sylfum gewræc.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 Dorme lo ’ngegno tuo, se non estima 65 per singular cagione esser eccelsa 66 lei tanto e sì travolta ne la cima.
query.result:
**English:**
64 Your intellect is asleep if it does not perceive 65 that she is exalted for a unique reason 66 and so turned upside down at the top.
**Old English:**
64 Slæpð þin ingehygd, gif he ne gesihð 65 ðurh âne ðing ðæt hio sîe sellic 66 and swâ gewended on ðære hyhstan.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 E se stati non fossero acqua d’Elsa 68 li pensier vani intorno a la tua mente, 69 e ’l piacer loro un Piramo a la gelsa,
70 per tante circostanze solamente 71 la giustizia di Dio, ne l’interdetto, 72 conosceresti a l’arbor moralmente.
query.result:
**English:**
67 And if the waters of Elsa had not been 68 the vain thoughts circling your mind, 69 and their pleasure a Pyramus to the mulberry,
70 through so many circumstances alone 71 the justice of God, in the interdict, 72 you would recognize morally in the tree.
**Old English:**
67 And gif ða wæteru ðære Ælsan næron 68 ða ydelu gedancas ymb ðine mod, 69 and heora willan sum Pyramus ðære mulberian,
70 ðurh swa fela ymbstænda ana 71 ðæs Godes rihtwisnes, on ðam interdicte, 72 ðu gecneowe ðone treow ðurh ða gesceadwisnesse.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
73 Ma perch’ io veggio te ne lo ’ntelletto 74 fatto di pietra e, impetrato, tinto, 75 sì che t’abbaglia il lume del mio detto,
76 voglio anco, e se non scritto, almen dipinto, 77 che ’l te ne porti dentro a te per quello 78 che si reca il bordon di palma cinto».
query.result:
**English:**
73 But because I see you in your intellect 74 become stone and, turned to stone, painted, 75 so that the light of my words dazzles you,
76 I want you also, and if not written, at least painted, 77 to carry it within you through that 78 for which one takes up the staff, bound with palm.
**Old English:**
73 Ac forðæm ic ðe geseo on ðinum ðonce 74 gewordenne stan and, geworden to stane, geglencged, 75 swa ðæt ðe ðæs leohtes mines wordes ablendð,
76 ic wille ðeah, and gif hit na ne bið awriten, ðeah ðæt ðu hit gewriten hæbbe, 77 ðæt ðu ðæt ðe in ðe læde ðurh ðæt 78 ðurh ðæt mon nimð ðone bord mid ðære palman begyrdedne.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 E io: «Sì come cera da suggello, 80 che la figura impressa non trasmuta, 81 segnato è or da voi lo mio cervello.
query.result:
**English:**
79 And I: "Just as wax from a seal, 80 which does not change the imprinted figure, 81 so is my brain now stamped by you.
**Old English:**
79 And ic: "Swa swa wex fram in-segle, 80 ðæt ða hiw ne awent, 81 is nu ðin hiw on minum breoste."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
82 Ma perché tanto sovra mia veduta 83 vostra parola disïata vola, 84 che più la perde quanto più s’aiuta?».
query.result:
**English:**
82 But why does your desired speech fly so high above my understanding, 83 that it loses it the more it tries to help itself?
**Old English:**
82 Ac for hwi swa heah ofer min geðoht 83 ðin word gewrixled fleogeð, 84 ðæt hit ðe mare forlyst ðe hit self mare hilpeð?

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
91 Ond’ io rispuosi lei: «Non mi ricorda 92 ch’i’ stranïasse me già mai da voi, 93 né honne coscïenza che rimorda».
query.result:
**English:**
91 And I answered her: "I do not remember 92 that I ever strayed from you, 93 nor have I any conscience that accuses me."
**Old English:**
91 And ic hire andswarode: "Ne mæg ic ðe secgan 92 ðæt ic æfre fram ðe gewende, 93 ne ic næfre nænne yfeles gemyndig ne eom."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
100 Veramente oramai saranno nude 101 le mie parole, quanto converrassi 102 quelle scovrire a la tua vista rude».
query.result:
**English:**
100 Truly now my words will be bare, 101 as much as it will be necessary 102 to reveal them to your unrefined sight.
**Old English:**
100 Soðlice nu ða beoð nacode 101 mine word, swa hit bið neod 102 ðæt ðu ða onwreo ðinum reðan rude.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 E più corusco e con più lenti passi 104 teneva il sole il cerchio di merigge, 105 che qua e là, come li aspetti, fassi,
106 quando s’affisser, sì come s’affigge 107 chi va dinanzi a gente per iscorta 108 se trova novitate o sue vestigge,
109 le sette donne al fin d’un’ombra smorta, 110 qual sotto foglie verdi e rami nigri 111 sovra suoi freddi rivi l’alpe porta.
query.result:
**English:**
103 And more radiant and with slower steps 104 the sun held the circle of midday, 105 which here and there, as the aspects are, grows,
106 when it sets, just as one sets 107 who goes before people as a guide 108 if he finds something new or traces of it,
109 the seven ladies at the end of a dim shade, 110 such as the Alps bear over their cold streams 111 under green leaves and black branches.
**Old English:**
103 And brihtor and mid læssan stepe 104 heold se sunne his merig-stede, 105 ðe her and ðær, swa ða gesceaftas synd, weaxað,
106 ðonne he sig set, swa swa se ðe set 107 ðe gæð beforan mannum to wisianne 108 gif he niwihte oððe his spor findeð,
109 ða seofon wimmen æt ðæs sceаdes ende, 110 swylce under grene leafe and blacum telgum 111 ofer ða cealdan burnas ða beorgas berað.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 Dinanzi ad esse Ëufratès e Tigri 113 veder mi parve uscir d’una fontana, 114 e, quasi amici, dipartirsi pigri.

Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 «O luce, o gloria de la gente umana, 116 che acqua è questa che qui si dispiega 117 da un principio e sé da sé lontana?».
query.result:
**English:**
115 O light, O glory of the human race, 116 what is this water that here unfolds 117 from a single source and yet is distant from itself?
**Old English:**
115 Eala, leoht, eala, beorhtra gebyrdu, 116 hwæt is ðeos wæter ðe her wynsum bið 117 of anum welme and wyrmum feor?

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 Per cotal priego detto mi fu: «Priega 119 Matelda che ’l ti dica». E qui rispuose, 120 come fa chi da colpa si dislega,
121 la bella donna: «Questo e altre cose 122 dette li son per me; e son sicura 123 che l’acqua di Letè non gliel nascose».
query.result:
**English:**
118 Because of such a prayer it was said to me: "Pray 119 Matilda that she tell it to you." And here she replied, 120 like one who frees herself from blame,
121 the beautiful lady: "This and other things 122 were told to him by me; and I am certain 123 that the water of Lethe did not hide it from him."
**Old English:**
118 For ðære bene ðæs gebedes wæs me ðus gecweden: "Bidde 119 Mathildan ðæt heo ðe hit secge." And ðær andwyrde, 120 swa ðe ðe ðe fram gylte alyseð,
121 seo fægere wif: "Ðis and oðre ðing 122 him wæron ðurh me gesæde; and ic eom gearo 123 ðæt ðæt wæter ðæs Lethes ðæt him ne beloc."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 E Bëatrice: «Forse maggior cura, 125 che spesse volte la memoria priva, 126 fatt’ ha la mente sua ne li occhi oscura.
query.result:
**English:**
124 And Beatrice: "Perhaps a greater care, 125 which often deprives the memory, 126 has made his mind dark in his eyes.
**Old English:**
124 And Bēatrice: "Þonne mæg hit wēsan māre giēmn, 125 ðe oft ðone mod benimeð, 126 ðe ðone hige gedrēfeð on ðām ēagum."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Ma vedi Eünoè che là diriva: 128 menalo ad esso, e come tu se’ usa, 129 la tramortita sua virtù ravviva».
query.result:
**English:**
127 But see Eunoë which flows there: 128 lead him to it, and as you are accustomed, 129 revive his dead virtue».
**Old English:**
127 Ac geseoh ðu ðæt Eunoe ðær oferswimoð: 128 læd hine ðærto, and swa ðu eart gewunod, 129 his forlorene miht ðu ðær geedstaðelie».

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
142 Io ritornai da la santissima onda 143 rifatto sì come piante novelle 144 rinovellate di novella fronda,
145 puro e disposto a salire a le stelle.
query.result:
**English:**
142 I returned from the most holy wave 143 remade, like new plants 144 renewed with new leaves,
145 pure and ready to ascend to the stars.
**Old English:**
142 Ic gewende fram ðære halgan wæge 143 geworht swa swa niwe plantan 144 niwum leafum niwe geworden,
145 clæne and gearu to stigenne to ðam steorrum.
